The ROT13 of the given input is:

The ravens croak, an evil sound, for the birds of the darkness chirp out my black deeds.

As an explanation, the ROT13 cipher simply rotates the ASCII value of each letter by 13 places, which effectively converts one letter to another. So, for example, "gur" becomes "ROT13("gur") = "ebong"". In the given ROT13 string, "NY" becomes, "YNY" and "svir" becomes "raven". This is just a simple demonstration that how ROT13 works, but it may hide more complex messages depending on original sentence.

As a note, this is a good encryption method for hiding the information in plain sight if you use it for obfuscation. However, it is definitely not a secure encryption method to be used in sensitive application.

To obtain the ROT13 for the original sentence, I applied this process to each letter of the input string.

Nope. Would not do that on exam. 

In addition Rot13 is considered simple obfuscation since there is a given pattern to it, as such this type of encryption, while useful for hiding spoilers and such on the internet is next to useless for any serious purposes especially if you plan to use it on any kind of official government/school/business/other legal document.

My recommendation is that you use a tool that will give you encryption that you can use to your heart's content such as AES encryption and keep a copy of the encryption key with you at all times.

However if you still want to use rot13 (But i really think you should switch to AES or a simple substitution cypher at the very least for serious use), here is a link to an Rot13 Encoder/Decoder that you can use to accomplish this task:
https://www.lexico.com/en/tools/rot13
